summary: A Daily Beast article from October 29, 2019, reporting that federal prosecutors from the Southern District of New York are actively meeting with victims of Jeffrey Epstein to line up witnesses for a continuing investigation into his alleged co-conspirators. The article details meetings in Florida and New York, discusses the victims' distrust due to the 2008 plea deal, and mentions several potential accomplices under scrutiny.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the sex-trafficking case who died by suicide in August 2019. The article discusses the ongoing investigation into his alleged co-conspirators and his assets.

persons.name: Kate Briquelet
persons.context: Author of the Daily Beast article being analyzed.

persons.name: Pervaiz Shallwani
persons.role: Senior Editor & Writer, The Daily Beast
persons.context: Co-author/editor of the Daily Beast article being analyzed.

persons.name: Spencer Kuvin
persons.context: Palm Beach attorney representing two women abused by Epstein. He described meetings between victims and federal prosecutors in Florida.

persons.name: Duncan Levin
persons.role: Former Assistant U.S. Attorney, Managing Partner at Tucker Levin, PLLC
persons.context: Legal analyst quoted in the article, stating that Epstein's inner circle should be nervous and that prosecutors are likely investigating enablers and seeking asset forfeiture.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: Alleged madam and associate of Epstein
persons.context: Described as Epstein's alleged madam, accused of recruiting underage girls and participating in sexual abuse. Mentioned as a target in lawsuits and keeping a low profile.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.role: Talent scout, alleged associate of Epstein
persons.context: French talent scout accused in civil filings of procuring young models for Epstein. Authorities in France are investigating sexual misconduct claims against him.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney who sued the government over Epstein's lenient 2008 plea deal. He expressed trust that New York prosecutors are thoroughly investigating.

persons.name: Kenneth Marra
persons.context: Judge who ruled Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement was illegal but refused to scrap it, denying victims' requests for further relief.

persons.name: Michael Bachner
persons.context: Attorney who previously stated that an unnamed female employee (likely Sarah Kellen) never engaged in misconduct while employed by Epstein.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's alleged madam, accused of recruiting underage girls and facilitating his sexual abuse network.
Brunel, a talent scout, is accused in civil filings of procuring young models for Epstein to exploit.
Kuvin is an attorney representing two of Epstein's victims, advocating for them in meetings with prosecutors.
Edwards sued the U.S. government on behalf of victims over Epstein's lenient 2008 plea deal.

events.title: SDNY Meeting with Victims in Florida
events.description: Representatives from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York traveled to Florida to meet with several of Epstein's victims and their counsel, offering counseling and discussing potential witness roles.

events.title: SDNY Meeting with Victims in New York
events.description: Prosecutors met with victims at a federal building in New York to inform them of their rights and offer counseling services.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested and charged with sex-trafficking and conspiracy to commit sex-trafficking.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died in jail, ruled a suicide by hanging.

events.title: Epstein's Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty to state charges under a non-prosecution agreement with federal prosecutors that granted immunity to alleged accomplices, a deal later ruled illegal by Judge Marra.

keyFacts: Federal prosecutors from the SDNY are actively meeting with Epstein victims to line up witnesses for a continuing investigation into his alleged co-conspirators, holding meetings in Florida and New York in October 2019.
The article mentions specific alleged co-conspirators under scrutiny, including Ghislaine Maxwell and Jean-Luc Brunel, and references unnamed female employees accused of facilitating abuse.
Epstein's net worth was estimated at over $550 million, including $56M in cash and properties like his private island, Manhattan mansion, and estates in Palm Beach, New Mexico, and Paris.
Following a Miami Herald expos√© in late 2018, Epstein wired payments of $250,000 and $100,000 to two unnamed women who were listed as possible co-conspirators in his non-prosecution agreement.

In September 2019, Judge Kenneth Marra ruled Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement was illegal but refused to scrap it, denying victims' requests for further relief; an appeal is scheduled for January 2020.
